summary: a cross-sectional study was conducted to determine the prevalence of GI parasites of dromedary camel (Camelus dromedarius) and fat-tailed sheep (dhumba), and the prevalence of hemoparasites in camel from dhaka, Bangladesh. a total of 87 fecal samples (32 dhumba and 55 camel) and 55 camel blood samples were collected during September–October 2015. 59.4% dhumba (n = 19; 95% CI: 41–76) were positive for GI parasite, including Trichostrongylus spp. (n = 10; 31.3%; 95% CI: 16.1–50), Strongyloides spp. (n = 9; 28%; 95% CI: 13.8–46.8) only one established camel farm is found in Bangladesh, which excels in camel farming as well as dhumba farming. parasites affect production by reducing fertility and work capacity, decreasing food intake, and lowering weight gain and milk production. public health is in danger because of zoonotic parasites. the study protocol was reviewed and approved by the animal Ethical Experimentation Committee (AEEC) of Chittagong Veterinary and Animal
